segment.source: title: Manage Windows with PowerShell Direct
segment.target: title: Manage Windows with PowerShell Direct

segment.source: Manage Windows with PowerShell Direct
segment.target: Manage Windows with PowerShell Direct

segment.source: 12-Nov update.
segment.target: 12-Nov update.

segment.source: You can use PowerShell Direct to remotely manage a Windows 10 or Windows Server Technical Preview virtual machine from a Windows 10 or Windows Server Technical Preview Hyper-V host.
segment.target: You can use PowerShell Direct to remotely manage a Windows 10 or Windows Server Technical Preview virtual machine from a Windows 10 or Windows Server Technical Preview Hyper-V host.

segment.source: PowerShell Direct allows PowerShell management inside a virtual machine regardless of the network configuration or remote management settings on either the Hyper-V host or the virtual machine.
segment.target: PowerShell Direct allows PowerShell management inside a virtual machine regardless of the network configuration or remote management settings on either the Hyper-V host or the virtual machine.

segment.source: This makes it easier for Hyper-V Administrators to automate and script virtual machine management and configuration.
segment.target: This makes it easier for Hyper-V Administrators to automate and script virtual machine management and configuration.

segment.source: There are two ways to run PowerShell Direct:
segment.target: There are two ways to run PowerShell Direct:

segment.source: Create and exit a PowerShell Direct session using PSSession cmdlets
segment.target: Create and exit a PowerShell Direct session using PSSession cmdlets

segment.source: Run script or command with the Invoke-Command cmdlet
segment.target: Run script or command with the Invoke-Command cmdlet

segment.source: If you're managing older virtual machines, use Virtual Machine Connection (VMConnect) or configure a virtual network for the virtual machine.
segment.target: If you're managing older virtual machines, use Virtual Machine Connection (VMConnect) or configure a virtual network for the virtual machine.

segment.source: Create and exit a PowerShell Direct session using PSSession cmdlets
segment.target: Create and exit a PowerShell Direct session using PSSession cmdlets

segment.source: On the Hyper-V host, open Windows PowerShell as Administrator.
segment.target: On the Hyper-V host, open Windows PowerShell as Administrator.

segment.source: Run the one of the following commands to create a session by using the virtual machine name or GUID:
segment.target: Run the one of the following commands to create a session by using the virtual machine name or GUID:

segment.source: Run whatever commands you need to.
segment.target: Run whatever commands you need to.

segment.source: These commands run on the virtual machine that you created the session with.
segment.target: These commands run on the virtual machine that you created the session with.

segment.source: When you're done, run the following command to close the session:
segment.target: When you're done, run the following command to close the session:

segment.source: Note: If you're session won't connect, make sure you're using credentials for the virtual machine you're connecting to -- not the Hyper-V host.
segment.target: Note: If you're session won't connect, make sure you're using credentials for the virtual machine you're connecting to -- not the Hyper-V host.

segment.source: To learn more about these cmdlets, see Enter-PSSession and Exit-PSSession.
segment.target: To learn more about these cmdlets, see Enter-PSSession and Exit-PSSession.

segment.source: Run script or command with Invoke-Command cmdlet
segment.target: Run script or command with Invoke-Command cmdlet

segment.source: You can use the Invoke-Command cmdlet to run a pre-determined set of commands on the virtual machine.
segment.target: You can use the Invoke-Command cmdlet to run a pre-determined set of commands on the virtual machine.

segment.source: Here is an example of how you can use the Invoke-Command cmdlet where PSTest is the virtual machine name and the script to run (foo.ps1) is in the script folder on the C:/ drive:
segment.target: Here is an example of how you can use the Invoke-Command cmdlet where PSTest is the virtual machine name and the script to run (foo.ps1) is in the script folder on the C:/ drive:

segment.source: To run a single command, use the -ScriptBlock parameter:
segment.target: To run a single command, use the -ScriptBlock parameter:

segment.source: What's required to use PowerShell Direct?
segment.target: What's required to use PowerShell Direct?

segment.source: To create a PowerShell Direct session on a virtual machine,
segment.target: To create a PowerShell Direct session on a virtual machine,

segment.source: The virtual machine must be running locally on the host and booted.
segment.target: The virtual machine must be running locally on the host and booted.

segment.source: You must be logged into the host computer as a Hyper-V administrator.
segment.target: You must be logged into the host computer as a Hyper-V administrator.

segment.source: You must supply valid user credentials for the virtual machine.
segment.target: You must supply valid user credentials for the virtual machine.

segment.source: The host operating system must run Windows 10, Windows Server Technical Preview, or a higher version.
segment.target: The host operating system must run Windows 10, Windows Server Technical Preview, or a higher version.

segment.source: The virtual machine must run Windows 10, Windows Server Technical Preview, or a higher version.
segment.target: The virtual machine must run Windows 10, Windows Server Technical Preview, or a higher version.

segment.source: You can use the Get-VM cmdlet to check that the credentials you're using have the Hyper-V administrator role and to see which VMs are running locally on the host and booted.
segment.target: You can use the Get-VM cmdlet to check that the credentials you're using have the Hyper-V administrator role and to see which VMs are running locally on the host and booted.

segment.source: What can you do with PowerShell Direct?
segment.target: What can you do with PowerShell Direct?

segment.source: See PowerShell Direct snippets for numerous examples of how to use PowerShell Direct in your environment as well as tips and tricks for writing Hyper-V scripts with PowerShell.
segment.target: See PowerShell Direct snippets for numerous examples of how to use PowerShell Direct in your environment as well as tips and tricks for writing Hyper-V scripts with PowerShell.
